\appendix
\section{Evaluation of Quantum Four-Point Amplitude with Two
Independent Angles}

 Here we evaluate the four-point correlation function
 $\langle\s_\n(x_1)\s_{-\n}(x_2)\s_{-\l}(x_3)\s_{\l}(x_4)\rangle$.
 The calculation closely parallels the calculation for closed
 string amplitudes on orbifolds \cite{BKM}.
 As before we introduce the auxiliary correlators $g(z,w)$,
 $\bar{g}(z,w)$, $h(z,w)=-\bar{g}(z,w)$ and $\bar{h}(z,w)=-g(z,w)$
 as defined in section II.A. In terms of \begin{equation}
    \om_{\n,\l}(z)=(z-x_1)^{-\nu}(z-x_2)^{\nu-1}(z-x_3)^{-\l}(z-x_4)^{\l-1}\end{equation}
 these take the form \begin{equation}
 g(z,w)=\om_{1-\n,\l}(z)\om_{\n,1-\l}(w)\left(\frac{P(z,w)}{(z-w)^2}+A(\{x_i\})\right)\end{equation}\begin{equation}
 h(\bar{z},w)=\om_{\n,1-\l}(\bar{z})\om_{\n,1-\l}B(x_i) \end{equation} where
 \begin{equation} \label{cond}P(z,w)=\sum_{i,j=0}^2a_{ij}w^iz^j \end{equation} and the condition \begin{equation}
 g(z,w)\sim (z-w)^{-2}\end{equation} determines all coefficients $a_{ij}$
 except for $a_{20}$, $a_{11}$ and $a_{02}$ for which it provides
 two linear equations. Solving these for $a_{02}$ and $a_{11}$
  we find \beqa \langle T(z)\rangle=\lim_{w\rightarrow
    z}\left(g(z,w)-\frac{1}{(z-w)^2}\right)
    =\frac{A(\{x_i\})+z^2+a_{21}z+a_{20}}{(z-x_1)(z-x_2)(z-x_3)(z-x_4)}\\
    \NO +\frac 12
    \n(1-\n)\left(\frac{1}{(z-x_1)}-\frac{1}{(z-x_2)}\right)^2+ \frac 12
    \l(1-\l)\left(\frac{1}{(z-x_3)}-\frac{1}{(z-x_4)}\right)^2\\
    \NO -\left(\frac{\n}{(z-x_1)}+\frac{1-\n}{(z-x_2)}\right)
    \left(\frac{1-\l}{(z-x_3)}+\frac{\l}{(z-x_4)}\right)\eeqa
    where $a_{21}=-[(1-\n)x_1+\n x_2+\l x_3+(1-\l)x_4]$. The
    freedom in $a_{20}$ does not affect the final result since
    $A(\{x_i\})$ will be determined after $a_{20}$ is fixed.
    Fixing  \begin{equation}
    a_{20}=\frac12[(1-\n+\l)x_1x_3+(1-\n-\l)x_1x_4-(1-\n-\l)x_2x_3+(1+\n-\l)x_2x_4]\end{equation}
    and using $SL(2,\mathbb{R})$ invariance to set $x_1=0,\,\,
    x_2=x,\,\, x_3=1,\,\, x_4\rightarrow\infty$ we find \begin{equation}
    \partial_x Z_{qu}(x)=\frac
    12\frac{(1-\n-\l)}{x-1}-\frac{\n(1-\n)}{x}-\frac{(1-\n)(1-\l)}{x-1}+\frac{A(x)}{x(x-1)}\end{equation}
    where \begin{equation}
    A(x)=\lim_{x_4\rightarrow\infty}-x_4^{-1}A(\{x_i\})\end{equation}
    and
    \begin{equation}
    Z_{qu}(x)=\lim_{x_4\rightarrow\infty}|x_4|^{\l(1-\l)}\langle\s_\n(0)\s_{-\n}(x)\s_{-\l}(1)\s_{\l}(x_4)\rangle\end{equation}

    As before $A(x)$ is determined by imposing the quantum
    monodromy conditions \begin{equation}
    \int_{C_i}dX=\int_{C_i}d\bar{X}=0\end{equation} leading again to
    conditions (\ref{qmonodromy1}) and (\ref{qmonodromy2}).
    We  insert \begin{equation} g(z,w)\rightarrow [\frac
    12(1-\n-\l)x+(1-\l)(z-x)+A(x)]\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation} \bar{g}(z,w)\rightarrow B(x)\tilde{\om}_{\n,1-\l}(z)\end{equation}
    and arrive at the two equations
    \beqa[\frac12(1-\n-\l)x+A(x)]\int_{C_1}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)+(1-\l)\int_{C_1}dz(z-x)\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)\\ \NO -e^{-2\p
    i\n}B(x)\int_{C_1}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)=0 \eeqa and
     \beqa[\frac12(1-\n-\l)x+A(x)]\int_{C_2}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)+(1-\l)\int_{C_2}dz(z-x)\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)\\ \NO -
    B(x)\int_{C_2}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)=0. \eeqa
    To solve these we need the integrals \begin{equation}
    \int_{C_1}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)=e^{i\p(1-\n-\l)}B(\n,1-\n)K_1(x)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation}
    \int_{C_2}dz\tilde{\om}_{1-\n,\l}(z)=e^{i\p(1-\l)}B(1-\l,1-\n)(1-x)^{1-\n-\l}F_2(x)\end{equation}
    where \begin{equation} K_1(x)\equiv F(\n,\l;1,x)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation} K_2(x)\equiv F(1-\n,1-\l;1;x)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation} F_1(x)\equiv F(\n,\l;\n+\l,x)\end{equation} and \begin{equation} F_2(x)\equiv
    F(1-\n,1-\l;2-\n-\l,x).\end{equation} One also needs the following
    identities \begin{equation}
    (1-\n)(1-\l)F(\n,\l;2,x)=(1-\n-\l)K_1(x)+(1-x)\partial_x
    K_1(x)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation}
    (1-\n)(1-\l)F(1-\l,1-\n;3-\n-\l;1-x)=-(2-\n-\l)\partial_xF_2(1-x)\end{equation}
    \begin{equation}
    B(1-\n,1-\l)(1-x)^{1-\n-\l}F_2(1-x)=B(\n,\l)F_1(1-x)-B(1-\n,1-\l)B(\n,\l)(1-\n-\l)K_1(x)\end{equation}
    and \begin{equation} K_1(x)=(1-x)^{1-\n-\l}K_2(x).\end{equation} After some
    algebra we arrive at the desired result \begin{equation}
    2A(x)=x(1-x)\partial_x\log\left[B(\n,\l)F_1(1-x)K_2(x)+B(1-\n,1-\l)F_2(1-x)K_1(x)\right].\end{equation}
    Hence \begin{equation} Z_{qu}(x)={\rm
    const.}x^{-\n(1-\n)}(1-x)^{-\n\l}I(x)^{-1/2}\end{equation} where
    \begin{equation}
    I(x)\equiv (1-x)^{1-\n-\l}\left[B(\n,\l)F_1(1-x)K_2(x)+B(1-\n,1-\l)F_2(1-x)K_1(x)\right
    ].\label{Ix}\end{equation} For completeness let us also give the result for
    $B(x)$, namely \begin{equation} B(x)=\frac12 e^{-2\p
    i\l}x(1-x)^{(2-\n-\l)}\partial_x\log\left[\frac{B(\n,\l)F_1(1-x)K_2(x)+B(1-\n,1-\l)F_2(1-x)K_1(x)}{(K_2(x))^2}\right].\end{equation}
